title: Saskatoon faces record high levels of homelessness
snippets: The number of homeless individuals in Saskatoon has nearly tripled since 2022, putting the city amongst the highest rates of homelessness in the country.
titles: Saskatoon faces record high levels of homelessness
summary: The homeless population in Saskatoon has almost tripled since 2022, marking one of the highest rates of homelessness in Canada.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides basic awareness about the issue of homelessness in Saskatoon, but it lacks depth or insight. It does not offer any actionable insights, solutions, or a deeper understanding of the causes, trends, or impacts of this issue.

title: Top Russian security official dismisses Trump’s ‘playing with fire’ warning to Putin – US politics live
snippets:
Dmitry Medvedev responds to Trump’s warning that Putin is ‘playing with fire’ by suggesting the real danger is ‘WWIII’

Earlier this morning, Alan Garber, president of Harvard University, told NPR’s Morning Edition that elite institutions need to double down on their “commitment to the good of the nation” and “be firm in our commitments to what we stand for”.

Garber said he finds the measures taken by the Trump administration to be “perplexing”; while he acknowledges there is work to be done on campus regarding viewpoint diversity, he said he struggles to see a link between funding freezes and fighting antisemitism.

I think that we have heard from some people that they do feel that [Harvard lacks viewpoint diversity]. What is perplexing is the measures that they have taken to address these that don’t even hit the same people that they believe are causing the problems. Why cut off research funding? Sure, it hurts Harvard, but it hurts the country because after all, the research funding is not a gift. The research funding is given to universities and other research institutions to carry out work – research work – that the federal government designates as high-priority work. It is work that they want done. They are paying to have that work conducted. Shutting off that work does not help the country, even as it punishes Harvard, and it is hard to see the link between that and, say, antisemitism.

I would say that the federal government has the authority through the budgeting process to reallocate funds. But the question to ask is what problem is [Trump] trying to solve by doing that? The money that goes to research universities in the form of grants and contracts, which is almost all of the federal support that we get, is used to pay for work that we perform at the behest of the government. So in reallocating to some other use, including trade schools, it means that work just won’t be performed. So the right question is, is this the most effective use of federal funding? Do you really want to cut back on research dollars? I’m less concerned about whether it goes to a trade school or if it goes to some other project, like working on highways. The real question is, how much value does the federal government get from its expenditures on research? There is a lot of actual research demonstrating the returns to the American people have been enormous.

I would say that we need to be firm in our commitments to what we stand for. And what we stand for – I believe I speak for other universities – is education, pursuit of the truth, helping to educate people for better futures. And hopefully our own students, after they graduate from our institutions, go out and serve the world. In the end, we’re about producing and disseminating knowledge and serving our nation and our world. When we fail in that, then we can expect to be attacked. So number one, I think we all need to redouble our commitment to the good of the nation and the world. And I know my fellow leaders fully embrace that.

Continue reading...

titles: Top Russian security official dismisses Trump’s ‘playing with fire’ warning to Putin – US politics live
Top Russian security official dismisses Trump’s ‘playing with fire’ warning to Putin – US politics live
summary: Dmitry Medvedev warned that the real danger in the current geopolitical climate is 'WWIII,' responding to Trump's caution about Putin's actions. Meanwhile, Alan Garber, Harvard University's president, criticized the Trump administration's funding freezes for research as perplexing and disconnected from the fight against antisemitism. He emphasized the importance of research funding for the country's welfare and highlighted the need for universities to uphold their commitment to education, truth, and serving the nation. Garber questioned the effectiveness of reallocating federal research funds
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful context about the geopolitical climate and the importance of research funding. It also highlights the criticism of the Trump administration's funding freezes for research. However, it does not clearly highlight progress, solutions, or empowering knowledge.

title: Australia news live: Nationals meet to decide on reuniting Coalition; 9,000 still isolated after NSW floods
snippets:
Follow today’s news live

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Nationals frontbencher Bridget McKenzie has insisted her party never made free votes for cabinet members a condition of returning to Coalition with the Liberals, as the two parties draw closer to a deal.

McKenzie also took a shot at Liberal MPs who were giving her and her colleagues free advice. She told Channel Seven’s Sunrise:

There are many Liberal MPs who want to give us gratuitous advice about how to run our party room. I’m happy to give them membership forms if they’d like to join it. But a coalition works best when everybody respects the independence of both parties.

That wasn’t put to the room.

Continue reading...

Follow today’s news live

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Nationals frontbencher Bridget McKenzie has insisted her party never made free votes for cabinet members a condition of returning to Coalition with the Liberals, as the two parties draw closer to a deal.

McKenzie also took a shot at Liberal MPs who were giving her and her colleagues free advice. She told Channel Seven’s Sunrise:

There are many Liberal MPs who want to give us gratuitous advice about how to run our party room. I’m happy to give them membership forms if they’d like to join it. But a coalition works best when everybody respects the independence of both parties.

That wasn’t put to the room.

Continue reading...
titles: Australia news live: Nationals meet to decide on reuniting Coalition; 9,000 still isolated after NSW floods
Australia news live: Nationals meet to decide on reuniting Coalition; 9,000 still isolated after NSW floods
summary: Bridget McKenzie, a Nationals frontbencher, stated that her party did not make free votes for cabinet members a condition for rejoining the Coalition with the Liberals. As negotiations progress, she criticized Liberal MPs for offering unsolicited advice on how the Nationals should operate, emphasizing that mutual respect for each party's independence is crucial for a successful coalition. This statement comes amid ongoing discussions to solidify the partnership between the two parties.
constructiveness_reason: This story informs about the ongoing negotiations between the Nationals and the Liberals in Australia, providing some insight into the dynamics of the coalition. However, it does not provide actionable insights or a clear sense of progress or solutions.

title: Freelance writer found dead in Las Vegas container, police say
snippets:
Body of Matthew Kelemen found and roommate – who died in car chase last week – identified as suspect, officials say

The remains of a longtime freelance writer in Las Vegas were found last week inside a container at a downtown business, authorities said.

Las Vegas police said in a news release that they discovered the body of Matthew Kelemen, 56, while responding to a report “of a foul-smelling odor” coming from the container.

Continue reading...
titles: Freelance writer found dead in Las Vegas container, police say
summary: The body of 56-year-old freelance writer Matthew Kelemen was found inside a container at a downtown Las Vegas business, following a report of a foul odor. Las Vegas police have identified Kelemen's roommate, who died in a car chase last week, as the suspect in his death.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides basic awareness about a crime incident but doesn't offer any deeper understanding or actionable insights for the reader.

title: John Haliburton returns to Pacers game after missing 8 straight following run-in with Antetokounmpo
snippets: John Haliburton was forced to watch Indiana's previous eight postseason games from afar after he ran onto the court and confronted Bucks star Giannis Antetokounmpo following his son's last-second shot to eliminate Milwaukee for the second straight year, this time in five games.  Shortly after the game ended, Tyrese Haliburton acknowledged his father did the wrong thing and the elder Haliburton apologized on social media for his overexuberance.
titles: John Haliburton returns to Pacers game after missing 8 straight following run-in with Antetokounmpo
summary: John Haliburton was barred from attending Indiana's last eight postseason games after confronting Bucks' Giannis Antetokounmpo on the court, following his son's decisive shot that ousted Milwaukee. Tyrese Haliburton, his son, admitted his father's mistake, and John Haliburton apologized on social media for his actions.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about John Haliburton's return to the Pacers game after missing eight games. It also contextualizes the situation by explaining the reason for his absence. However, it does not report on any solutions, improvements, or innovations, nor does it increase clarity around systems, causes, trends, or impacts that matter.

title: Your Fingers Wrinkle in the Same Pattern Every Time
snippets: Research shows that fingers wrinkle in a consistent pattern each time they are immersed in water. Do your wrinkles always form in the same pattern after spending too much time in water? New research from Binghamton University, State University of New York, says they do. A few years ago, Binghamton University Associate Professor Guy German [...]
titles: Your Fingers Wrinkle in the Same Pattern Every Time
summary: Research from Binghamton University, State University of New York, has discovered that finger wrinkles form in a consistent pattern each time they are exposed to water. This study, led by Associate Professor Guy German, highlights the repeatability of wrinkle patterns on fingers after immersion in water, showcasing minor variations but high consistency over time.
constructiveness_reason: The story provides useful information about a biological phenomenon, enhancing the reader's understanding of the human body. However, it doesn't report on solutions, improvements, or innovations, and its practical implications are not immediately clear.

title: Why Are Coral Reefs Surrounded by Mysterious “Ghostly” Halos?
snippets: The study analyzes the spatial distribution patterns of “grazing halos” surrounding coral reefs. Around the world, coral reefs are often surrounded by noticeable bands of bare sand that appear clearly in satellite images, but the reason behind these patterns remains a mystery. One hypothesis is fear. Herbivorous fish like parrotfish leave the safety of the [...]
titles: Why Are Coral Reefs Surrounded by Mysterious “Ghostly” Halos?
summary: A study explored the phenomenon of "grazing halos" around coral reefs, characterized by bands of bare sand visible from satellite images. The cause of these patterns is not definitively known, but one theory suggests that herbivorous fish, such as parrotfish, create these halos by grazing near the reefs but avoiding more distant areas due to fear of predators. This behavior results in a clear zone around the reefs where the seabed is devoid of vegetation.
constructiveness_reason: This story increases awareness about an ecological phenomenon, providing insights into the behavior of herbivorous fish and their potential impact on the environment. It doesn't directly highlight solutions or improvements, but it does contribute to a deeper understanding of marine ecosystems.

title: “Living Fossil” – Elusive Insect Thought To Be Extinct Rediscovered After 40 Years
snippets: The Monte Gordo Grasshopper, a rare living fossil, was found again in Cape Verde, revealing its resilience in harsh environments. The Monte Gordo Grasshopper (Eyprepocprifas insularis) is one of the rarest and most elusive insect species. Until recently, its only recorded sighting was a single specimen collected in 1980. Based on the absence of any [...]
titles: “Living Fossil” – Elusive Insect Thought To Be Extinct Rediscovered After 40 Years
summary: The Monte Gordo Grasshopper (Eyprepocprifas insularis), considered a "living fossil" and thought to be extinct after its last sighting in 1980, has been rediscovered in Cape Verde. This rare and elusive insect species showcases its ability to survive in harsh environments, overturning previous assumptions about its extinction.
constructiveness_reason: The story provides useful information about a rare insect species, contributing to the reader's understanding of biodiversity and species survival. However, it doesn't report on solutions or improvements, nor does it provide actionable insights for the reader.

title: The extremes of imagination reveal how our brains perceive reality
snippets: The worlds inside our heads can be dramatically different. What does that reveal about how our minds shape our lives, asks cognitive neurologist Adam Zeman
titles: The extremes of imagination reveal how our brains perceive reality
summary: Cognitive neurologist Adam Zeman explores the significant differences in the mental worlds of individuals, questioning the impact of these internal landscapes on our lives. He delves into how our minds, with their unique perceptions and thoughts, shape our experiences and behaviors, highlighting the profound influence of our inner worlds on our external realities.
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive as it provides readers with a deeper understanding of cognitive neurology and how our internal perceptions shape our external realities. It increases awareness about the functioning of our minds and its impact on our experiences and behaviors.

title: Medieval woman was executed and displayed on London riverbank
snippets: A skeleton found in London records a brutal killing about 1200 years ago, thought to be a rare example of a judicial execution of a woman in medieval England
titles: Medieval woman was executed and displayed on London riverbank
summary: A skeleton discovered in London has been identified as a woman who was brutally killed around 1200 years ago, marking a rare instance of judicial execution from medieval England. This finding contributes to the historical understanding of justice and gender roles in that era.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it provides historical context and insights into justice and gender roles in medieval England. However, it doesn't offer actionable insights or report on solutions or improvements, hence the score is not higher.
